title: Adrianitidae
text:
Adrianitidae is a family in the <a href="Adrianitaceae">Adrianitaceae</a>, a superfamily of <a href="ammonites">ammonites</a> in the <a href="cephalopoda">cephalopod</a> order, <a href="Goniatitida">Goniatitida</a>, known from the <a href="Middle%20Pennsylvanian">Middle Pennsylvanian</a> to the <a href="Middle%20Permian">Middle Permian</a>.
Members of the Adrianitidae, named by <a href="Schindewolf">Schindewolf</a> in 1931, and of the Adrianitaceae, have shells (conchs) that are discoidal to globular with umbilici that vary in form, and sutures with 10 to 30, more or less equal, lobes.
The Adrianitinae which come from the Lower and Middle Permian have sutures that form 14 to 30 lobes. Genera included "Adrianites", "Hoffmannia", "Doryceras", "Crimites", and "Texoceras". 
The Dumbaritinae which come from the Middle and Upper <a href="Pennsylvanian%20%28geology%29">Pennsylvanian</a> (U Carb) have sutures with only 10 lobes. "Clinolobus", from the Middle Permian of Sicily, has about 14 lobes with the course of the external suture forming a V.
Classification.
The Adriantidae contains three subfamilies, the Adrianitinae, Hoffmanniinae, and Texoceratinae. Most of the genera in the family, some 15 in number, are included in the Adrianitinae. The remaining two are included, one each, in the Hoffmanniinae and Texoceratinae.
"<a href="Dunbarites">Dunbarites</a>" and "<a href="Clinolobus">Clinolobus</a>" included in the Adrianantidae in the older edition of <a href="Treatise%20on%20Invertebrate%20Paleontology">Treatise</a> (Part L) have since then been reassigned; "Dunbarites" to the <a href="Schistocerataceae">Schistocerataceae</a> and "Clinolobus" to the <a href="Neoicocerataceae">Neoicocerataceae</a>
The <a href="Emilitinae">Emilitinae</a>, established to include the most primitive members of the family, based on "<a href="Emilites">Emilites</a>", have been reincorporated into the Adrianitinae. "<a href="Pamiritella">Pamiritella</a>" for which the <a href="Pamiritellinae">Pamiritellinae</a> was established is considered also part of the Adrianitinae. 
Phylogeny.
According to Saunders et al. (1999), the Adrianitidae are derived from "<a href="Clistoceras">Clistoceras</a>", a genus in the <a href="Somholitaceae">Somholitaceae</a>, through "Emilites", which in turn is the source for "<a href="Pseudoemilites">Pseudoemilites</a>" and "<a href="Crimites">Crimites</a>". "Pseudoemilites" resulted in small groups that include "<a href="Veruzhites">Veruzhites</a>" and "<a href="Nevadoceras">Nevadoceras</a>" as well. "Crimites" on the other hand gave rise to "<a href="Neocrimites">Neocrimites</a>" and "<a href="Pamiritella">Pamiritella</a>" which respectively are the source for the Adrianitinae and Pameritellinae. "Crimites" also gave rise to "<a href="Aricoceras">Aricoceras</a>" and "<a href="Neoaricoceras">Neoaricoceras</a>". The source for either "Hoffmannia" or "Texoceras" is unknown.
Older Taxonomy.
In the taxonomies put forth by Miller, Furnish, and Schindewolf (ca 1960) in the <a href="Treatise%20on%20Invertebrate%20Paleontology">Treatise on Invertebrate Paleontology, Part L, Ammonoidea</a>, the Adrianitidae is divided into three subfamilies, the more advanced Adrianitinae based on "Adrianites", the more primitive Dunbaritinae containing "<a href="Dunbarites">Dunbarites</a>" and "Emilites", and the Clinolobitinae with just "<a href="Clinolobus">Clinolobus</a>".
